profile.title: Excellent Kit!
profile.text:
I'm just getting back into using a safety razor after decades of using a multiblade cartridge razor and/or really high end electric shavers, and I'm very happy with this kit. Functionality wise, is just excellent. It's easy to switch out blades, nice weight to it, nice grip. I also really like the brush and stand and the look of the whole set displayed in my bathroom. It's great when a razor works well, but it's even better when it looks great for the 23.5 hours per day that you're not using it.

The blades that come with the set seem decent, but I also ordered a 15 brand 2-blade variety pack, and will be going through each of these brands to find the one(s) I like the most.

If you're just getting back into safety razor shaving like me or if you're doing this for the first time, hang in there. Watching a few YouTube videos will help you. Most importantly, do not treat this like a multi-blade, lubricated cartridge razor. Safety razors are one-pass razors, do not apply pressure, and don't shy away from pre/after shaving skin/beard conditioners, lotions, etc. When you do everything right, this single blade will give you the best, closest shave you've ever had.

profile.title: Feels nice on skin but not thrilled with the scent
profile.text: I love using a gel for my Summer overnight moisturizer because it has a more cooling feel on my skin for those warmer nights. This gel is a bit closer to a lotion in viscosity but would still work on a warm evening. However, it smells like a bar of basic everyday soap and it's not a "relaxing" smell by any stretch of the imagination. The refreshing/clean scent might work better as a daytime moisturizer but it's not something I want to smell on my bed pillow. Some might not be bothered by the scent in which case it would probably work very well for them either day or night. The packaging is classy-looking and size is generous, especially when touted as a travel size.

profile.title: Doesn't do anything that a reused margarine tub doesn't do
profile.text:
Thanks to a series of unfortunate events involving a car accident AND a bike accident, I am the (not so) proud owner of a partial denture. For quite a while, I just used two old margarine tubs to soak my denture. (Pro tip: soak your denture in plain water in a separate container and then rinse it thoroughly before putting it in the cleaning solution, and then your cleaning solution won't get nasty.) But when the lids of my margarine tubs started to crack, I decided to get some "real" denture cups. Yeah...I should have just eaten some more margarine and washed out a new tub.

These cups are not in the least impressive. The lid of the blue cup snaps shut but isn't remotely leakproof--tip it just slightly and you'll have water or cleaning solution sloshing all over. The lid of the white cup doesn't even snap shut. It just barely rests on top of the cup and strainer, and if you don't watch what you're doing when you pick up the container, you'll find yourself holding the lid and looking at the cup and water/solution all over the floor. Furthermore, the two cups are far too hard to stack. The white one can't go on top of the blue one because the lid of the blue one is curved, but putting the blue one on top of the white one is precarious because the blue one is wider. And I find it surprisingly annoying to have two containers that won't stack taking up twice as much space as necessary in my tiny bathroom. About the only feature of these cups that is at all handy is the little strainer thing, and since my denture is plastic and floats, I don't find even that feature very useful.

Bottom line: you can soak dentures in pretty much any container, and you can find two small plastic containers with flat tops and secure lids for considerably less than the cost of these. Toast with margarine, anyone?

profile.title: Works great! Best curling device I’ve owned so far!
profile.text:
I’ve been growing out my short hair and I took a chance on this bubble wand! I love it! Super good value for the price ! But there is a learning curve when using it. Takes a little practice to get it down, and you do need to wear the heat glove so you don’t burn your fingers. My hair never held curl well , but with this iron I can go to sleep and still have curls the next day!! I do use a thermal protection firm hair spray and that probably helps the curls stay in longer.

Also love how this wand doesn’t accidentally shut off when using it! Buy it now, so great for the price!

profile.title: Great curling wand.
profile.text: O.k, let me start off by saying that I have never learned to curl my hair. I am a total dummy when it comes to working a curling iron of any kind. I have naturally curly(2b or 2c on a good day) and sometimes I get spots where my hair just falls limp and doesn't want to curl that day. That's why I wanted a curling wand, so I can add curls to the spots where nature took a break. I decided to give this a try and I was actually able to get a curl out of it. Now there is a learning curve and it was not perfect my first time but it was better than anything I have ever been able to do. I am so happy. The only thing I didn't like was that the curl didn't last that long in my hair but to be fair neither did my natural curls. Would totally recommend.

profile.title: I wish there was an extra long version TIGI
profile.text: I absolutely LOVE the curl that this gives. However, it is NOT long enough for long hair. I am only 5'5" and my hair goes only to my bra strap. I have to start the curly in the middle of my hair or have a whole inch at the bottom that is straight. PLEASE make an XL (extra long) version of this TIGI.

profile.title: So easy and it works
profile.text: I'm not great at doing my hair, and honestly I've never been - even though I have straight hair.  Recently I got a long shag haircut which I love.  It's really easy to manage, but I still want to give it some style so sometimes I use a diffuser and sometimes when I want more structure to it, I use this curling wand.  It's so easy to use since you just wrap sections of your hair around it - I use the rounded sections since I just want a bit of a wave, though if you want more of a curl just wrap your hair around the smaller sections of the wand.  It heats up quickly, and honestly can't say enough good things about it.

profile.title: Hard to use if not impossible on short hair
profile.text: I got this to do my daughter's [ above the shoulder length ] hair for prom.  It arrived on time and quickly which was great. There were no directions explaining how to use the curling wand so I had to Google instructions. It heats up fairly quickly and I like the color of it. When I tried curling my daughter's hair though it was almost impossible. It came out looking more like a kink than a curl. Almost like when you take a hair tie out after sleeping in it and your hair will have an imprint of the hair tie...it was kinked not curled. I ended up having to pay to take her to the salon so they could curl her hair which they did using a regular wand. So ultimately I think this works fine on hair that is below shoulder length and anything shorter I'd say get something else.
